title.text: DUTH at SemEval-2017 Task 5: Sentiment Predictability in Financial Microblogging and News Articles

abstractContent.text: We present the system developed by the team DUTH for the participation in Semeval-2017 task 5-Fine-Grained Sentiment Analysis on Financial Microblogs and News, in subtasks A and B.

entities.text: Semeval-2017 task 5-Fine-Grained Sentiment Analysis on Financial Microblogs and News

abstractContent.text: Our approach to determine the sentiment of Mi-croblog Messages and News Statements & Headlines is based on linguistic pre-processing, feature engineering, and supervised machine learning techniques.

entities.text: determine the sentiment of Mi-croblog Messages and News Statements & Headlines

abstractContent.text: To train our model, we used Neural Network Regression, Linear Regression, Boosted Decision Tree Regression and Decision Forrest Regression classifiers to forecast sentiment scores.
At the end, we present an error measure, so as to improve the performance about forecasting methods of the system.

introductionContent.text: Social media sentiment is an important indicator of public opinion.
Determining sentiment can be valuable in a number of applications including brand awareness, product launches, and detecting political trends.
Many microblogging platforms such as Twitter and StockTwits have become very popular and are employed by many traders and investors.

Recently, many studies (Piñeiro-Chousa This paper describes our submissions to SemEval 2017 task 5 (, which deals with sentiment analysis in microblog messages for SubTask A, and sentences for news headlines for SubTask B.
In SubTask A, our model was ranked last because of a submission format error.
We perform error measures in order to obtain a better understanding of the strengths of these particularly new tasks and to improve the performance about forecasting methods of our model.
For Subtask B, our team was ranked 24th from 29 teams.
The rest of this paper is structured as follows: Section 2 provides our system's description.
Section 3 presents the experiments and some unofficial results used in analyzing the system's performance.
Finally, conclusions and further directions for research are presented in Section 4.

datasetContent.text: The Task 5 organizers () provided a training and testing set for both subtasks.
